001package squidpony;
002
003import regexodus.*;
004import squidpony.squidmath.*;
005
006import java.io.Serializable;
007import java.util.ArrayList;
008import java.util.Collection;
009import java.util.Iterator;
010import java.util.Map;
011
012import static squidpony.Maker.makeList;
013import static squidpony.Maker.makeOM;
014
015/**
016 * A text processing class that can swap out occurrences of special keywords and replace them with randomly-selected
017 * synonyms. For example, this can take {@code "By the light`adj` fire`noun` in my heart, I will vanquish thee!"}, which
018 * has the keywords {@code light`adj`} and {@code fire`noun`}, and could produce
019 * {@code "By the shimmering inferno in my heart, I will vanquish thee!"} on one run, and
020 * {@code "By the gleaming conflagration in my heart, I will vanquish thee!"} on another. This can also generate some
021 * plant names and basic descriptions of potions, as well as make some text sound like {@link #ORK}. 
022 * <br>
023 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 5/23/2016.
024 */
025public class Thesaurus implements Serializable{
026    private static final long serialVersionUID = 3387639905758074640L;
027    protected static final Pattern wordMatch = Pattern.compile("([\\pL`]+|@)"),
028            similarFinder = Pattern.compile(".*?\\b(\\w\\w\\w\\w).*?{\\@1}.*$", "ui");
029    public OrderedMap<CharSequence, GapShuffler<String>> mappings;
030    public ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen.Alteration> alterations = new ArrayList<>(4);
031    public SilkRNG rng;
032    protected GapShuffler<String> plantTermShuffler, fruitTermShuffler, nutTermShuffler, flowerTermShuffler,
033            potionTermShuffler;
034    public FakeLanguageGen defaultLanguage = FakeLanguageGen.SIMPLISH;
035    public transient ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen> randomLanguages = new ArrayList<>(2);
036    public transient String latestGenerated = "Nationia";
037    /**
038     * Constructs a new Thesaurus with an unseeded RNG used to shuffle word order.
039     */
040    public Thesaurus()
041    {
042        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
043        rng = new SilkRNG();
044        addKnownCategories();
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with the next long from the given RNG.
049     * @param rng an RNG that will only be used to get one long (for seeding this class' RNG)
050     */
051    public Thesaurus(IRNG rng)
052    {
053        this(rng.nextLong());
054    }
055
056    /**
057     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
058     * @param shuffleSeed a long for seeding this class' RNG
059     */
060    public Thesaurus(long shuffleSeed)
061    {
062        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
063        this.rng = new SilkRNG(shuffleSeed);
064        addKnownCategories();
065    }
066
067
068    /**
069     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
070     * @param shuffleSeed a String for seeding this class' RNG
071     */
072    public Thesaurus(String shuffleSeed)
073    {
074        this(CrossHash.hash64(shuffleSeed));
075    }
076
077    /**
078     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
079     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
080     * @param state any long; will be given to {@link SilkRNG#setState(long)}
081     */
082    public void refresh(long state)
083    {
084        refresh((int)(state & 0xFFFFFFFFL), (int)(state >>> 32));
085    }
086
087    /**
088     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
089     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
090     * @param stateA any int; the first part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
091     * @param stateB any int; the second part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
092     */
093    public void refresh(int stateA, int stateB)
094    {
095        this.rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
096        final int sz = mappings.size();
097        for (int i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
098            mappings.getAt(i).setRNG(rng, true);
099        }
100    }
101
102    public Thesaurus addReplacement(CharSequence before, String after)
103    {
104        mappings.put(before, new GapShuffler<>(after));
105        return this;
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * Allows this Thesaurus to replace a specific keyword, typically containing multiple backtick characters
110     * ({@code `}) so it can't be confused with a "real word," with one of the words in synonyms (chosen in shuffled
111     * order). The backtick is the only punctuation character that this class' word matcher considers part of a word,
112     * both for this reason and because it is rarely used in English text.
113     * @param keyword a word (typically containing backticks, {@code `}) that will be replaced by a word from synonyms
114     * @param synonyms a Collection of lower-case Strings with similar meaning and the same part of speech
115     * @return this for chaining
116     */
117    public Thesaurus addCategory(String keyword, Collection<String> synonyms)
118    {
119        if(synonyms.isEmpty())
120            return this;
121        GapShuffler<String> shuffler = new GapShuffler<>(synonyms, rng, true);
122        mappings.put(keyword, shuffler);
123        return this;
124    }
125
126    /**
127     * Adds several pre-made categories to this Thesaurus' known categories, but won't cause it to try to replace normal
128     * words with synonyms (only categories, which contain backticks in the name). The keywords this currently knows,
129     * and the words it will replace those keywords with, are:
130     * <br>
131     * <ul>
132     *     <li>calm`adj` : calm, harmonious, peaceful, placid, pleasant, serene, tranquil</li>
133     *     <li>calm`noun` : calm, harmony, kindness, peace, serenity, tranquility</li>
134     *     <li>org`noun` : association, brotherhood, fellowship, foundation, fraternity, group, guild, order, partnership</li>
135     *     <li>org`nouns` : associations, brotherhoods, fellowships, foundations, fraternities, groups, guilds, orders, partnerships</li>
136     *     <li>empire`adj` : ascendant, dynastic, emir's, hegemonic, imperial, king's, lordly, monarchic, prince's, regal, royal, sultan's</li>
137     *     <li>empire`noun` : ascendancy, commonwealth, dominion, dynasty, emirate, empire, hegemony, imperium, kingdom, monarchy, sultanate, triumvirate</li>
138     *     <li>empire`nouns` : ascendancies, commonwealths, dominions, dynasties, emirates, empires, hegemonies, imperia, kingdoms, monarchies, sultanates, triumvirates</li>
139     *     <li>emperor`noun` : emir, emperor, king, lord, pharaoh, ruler, sultan</li>
140     *     <li>emperor`nouns` : emirs, emperors, kings, lords, pharaohs, rulers, sultans</li>
141     *     <li>empress`noun` : emira, empress, lady, pharaoh, queen, ruler, sultana</li>
142     *     <li>empress`nouns` : emiras, empresses, ladies, pharaohs, queens, rulers, sultanas</li>
143     *     <li>union`adj` : allied, associated, confederated, congressional, democratic, federated, independent, people's, unified, united</li>
144     *     <li>union`noun` : alliance, coalition, confederacy, confederation, congress, faction, federation, league, republic, union</li>
145     *     <li>union`nouns` : alliances, coalitions, confederacies, confederations, congresses, factions, federations, leagues, republics, unions</li>
146     *     <li>militia`noun` : fighters, front, irregulars, liberators, militants, militia, rebellion, resistance, warriors</li>
147     *     <li>militia`nouns` : fighters, fronts, irregulars, liberators, militants, militias, rebellions, resistances, warriors</li>
148     *     <li>gang`noun` : cartel, crew, gang, mafia, mob, posse, syndicate</li>
149     *     <li>gang`nouns` : cartels, crews, gangs, mafias, mobs, posses, syndicates</li>

153     *     <li>duchy`nouns` : baronies, duchies, earldoms, fiefdoms, lordships, shogunates</li>
154     *     <li>magical`adj` : arcane, enchanted, ensorcelled, magical, mystical, sorcerous</li>
155     *     <li>holy`adj` : auspicious, blessed, divine, godly, holy, prophetic, sacred, virtuous</li>
156     *     <li>priest`noun` : bishop, cardinal, chaplain, cleric, preacher, priest</li>
157     *     <li>priest`nouns` : bishops, cardinals, chaplains, clergy, preachers, priests</li>
158     *     <li>unholy`adj` : accursed, bewitched, macabre, occult, profane, unholy, vile</li>
159     *     <li>witch`noun` : cultist, defiler, necromancer, occultist, warlock, witch</li>
160     *     <li>witch`nouns` : cultists, defilers, necromancers, occultists, warlocks, witches</li>
161     *     <li>forest`adj` : bountiful, fertile, lush, natural, primal, verdant</li>
162     *     <li>forest`noun` : copse, forest, glen, greenery, grove, jungle, nature, woodland</li>
163     *     <li>shaman`noun` : animist, druid, shaman, warden</li>
164     *     <li>shaman`nouns` : animists, druids, shamans, wardens</li>
165     *     <li>fancy`adj` : glorious, grand, great, magnanimous, magnificent, majestic, powerful</li>

172     *     <li>lethal`adj` : bloodstained, cutthroat, deadly, fatal, lethal, murderous, poisonous, silent, stalking, venomous</li>
173     *     <li>lethal`noun` : assassin, blood, killer, murder, ninja, poison, razor, silence, slayer, snake, tiger, venom</li>
174     *     <li>blade`noun` : axe, blade, cutlass, flail, glaive, halberd, hammer, hatchet, katana, knife, lance, mace, maul, nunchaku, saber, scimitar, scythe, sickle, spear, stiletto, sword, trident, whip</li>
175     *     <li>bow`noun` : atlatl, bolas, bow, crossbow, dagger, javelin, longbow, net, shortbow, shuriken, sling</li>

180     *     <li>blade`nouns` : axes, blades, cutlasses, flails, glaives, halberds, hammers, hatchets, katana, knives, lances, maces, mauls, nunchaku, sabers, scimitars, scythes, sickles, spears, stilettos, swords, tridents, whips</li>

183     *     <li>musket`nouns` : arquebusses, blunderbusses, cannons, flintlocks, matchlocks, muskets, wheellocks</li>
184     *     <li>grenade`nouns` : bombs, explosives, flamethrowers, grenades, missiles, rockets, warheads</li>

186     *     <li>scifi`adj` : genetic, gravitational, laser, nanoscale, phase, photonic, plasma, quantum, tachyonic, warp</li>

199     *     <li>lightning`nouns` : lightning, shocks, sparks, storms, thunder, thunderbolts</li>

206     *     <li>tree`noun` : alder, beech, birch, cactus, cedar, elm, hazel, juniper, larch, magnolia, mangrove, maple, oak, palm, pine, tree, willow</li>
207     *     <li>flavor`noun` : acid, grease, herb, salt, smoke, spice, sugar</li>
208     *     <li>flavor`adj` : bitter, salty, savory, smoky, sour, spicy, sweet</li>
209     *     <li>color`adj` : black, blue, brown, gray, green, orange, red, violet, white, yellow</li>
210     *     <li>shape`adj` : delicate, drooping, fibrous, fragile, giant, hardy, hollow, long, miniature, spiny, stiff, stubby, sturdy, thorny, tufted, yielding</li>
211     *     <li>sensory`adj` : aromatic, fragrant, fuzzy, glossy, pungent, rough, rustling, smooth, soft, weeping</li>
212     *     <li>liquid`noun` : brew, broth, elixir, fluid, liquid, potion, serum, tonic</li>

218     *     <li>smart`noun` : acumen, awareness, cunning, genius, knowledge, mindfulness, smarts, wisdom</li>
219     *     <li>stupid`adj` : careless, complacent, dull, dumb, foolish, idiotic, moronic, reckless, sloppy, stupid</li>
220     *     <li>stupid`noun` : carelessness, complacency, foolishness, idiocy, recklessness, sloppiness, stupidity</li>
221     *     <li>bandit`noun` : bandit, brigand, highwayman, pirate, raider, rogue, thief</li>
222     *     <li>bandit`nouns` : bandits, brigands, highwaymen, pirates, raiders, rogues, thieves</li>
223     *     <li>soldier`noun` : combatant, fighter, mercenary, soldier, trooper, warrior</li>
224     *     <li>soldier`nouns` : combatants, fighters, mercenaries, soldiers, troops, warriors</li>
225     *     <li>guard`noun` : defender, guard, guardian, knight, paladin, protector, sentinel, shield, templar, warden, watchman</li>
226     *     <li>guard`nouns` : defenders, guardians, guards, knights, paladins, protectors, sentinels, shields, templars, wardens, watchmen</li>
227     *     <li>hunter`noun` : hunter, poacher, stalker, tracker, trapper, warden</li>
228     *     <li>explorer`noun` : explorer, nomad, pathfinder, questant, seeker, wanderer</li>
229     *     <li>hunter`nouns` : hunters, poachers, stalkers, trackers, trappers, wardens</li>
230     *     <li>explorer`nouns` : explorers, nomads, pathfinders, questants, seekers, wanderers</li>
231     *     <li>rage`noun` : anger, frenzy, fury, rage, vengeance, wrath</li>
232     *     <li>ominous`adj` : baleful, fateful, foreboding, ominous, portentous</li>
233     *     <li>many`adj` : countless, infinite, manifold, many, myriad, thousandfold, unlimited</li>
234     *     <li>impossible`adj` : abominable, forbidden, impossible, incomprehensible, indescribable, ineffable, unearthly, unspeakable</li>
235     *     <li>gaze`noun` : eye, gaze, observation, purveyance, stare, watch</li>
236     *     <li>pain`noun` : agony, excruciation, misery, pain, torture</li>
237     *     <li>god`noun` : deity, father, god, king, lord, lordship, ruler</li>
238     *     <li>goddess`noun` : deity, goddess, lady, ladyship, mother, queen, ruler</li>
239     *     <li>hero`noun` : champion, crusader, hero, knight, savior</li>
240     *     <li>heroes`nouns` : champions, crusaders, heroes, knights, saviors</li>
241     *     <li>heroine`noun` : champion, crusader, heroine, knight, maiden, savior</li>
242     *     <li>heroines`nouns` : champions, crusaders, heroines, knights, maidens, saviors</li>
243     *     <li>popular`adj` : adored, beloved, revered, worshipped</li>
244     *     <li>unpopular`adj` : despised, hated, loathed, reviled</li>
245     *     <li>glyph`noun` : glyph, mark, seal, sigil, sign, symbol</li>
246     *     <li>glyph`nouns` : glyphs, marks, seals, sigils, signs, symbols</li>
247     *     <li>power`noun` : authority, dominance, force, potency, power, strength</li>
248     *     <li>power`adj` : authoritative, dominant, forceful, potent, powerful, strong</li>
249     * </ul>
250     * There are also terms, which typically produce multiple words procedurally and may use {@link #defaultLanguage}.
251     * See {@link #makePlantName()}, {@link #makeFruitName()}, {@link #makeNutName()}, {@link #makeFlowerName()}, and
252     * {@link #makePotionDescription()} for more info and examples.
253     * <li>
254     *     <li>plant`term` : @'s color`adj`     leaf`noun`, @'s color`adj` flower`noun`, @'s color`adj` tree`noun`, @'s flower`noun`, @'s ground`noun`  leaf`noun`, @'s sensory`adj`-leaf`noun`, @'s shape`adj` flower`noun`, @'s tree`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun` of @, color`adj` fruit`noun` tree`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun` tree`noun`, color`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, flavor`adj` fruit`noun` tree`noun`, flavor`adj` nut`noun` tree`noun`, flavor`noun` leaf`noun` tree`noun`, flower`noun` of @, ground`noun`  flower`noun`, ground`noun`      leaf`noun`, ground`noun`        leaf`noun` of @, leaf`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun`-flower`noun`, sensory`adj` tree`noun` of @, sensory`adj` tree`noun`-tree`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` tree`noun`, shape`adj` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-fruit`noun` tree`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` tree`noun`</li>
255     *     <li>fruit`term` : @'s color`adj` fruit`noun`, @'s flavor`adj` fruit`noun`, @'s fruit`noun`, color`adj` fruit`noun`-fruit`noun`, flavor`adj` fruit`noun`-fruit`noun`, fruit`noun` of @</li>
256     *     <li>nut`term` : @'s color`adj` nut`noun`, @'s flavor`adj` nut`noun`, @'s nut`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun` of @, flavor`adj` nut`noun`, nut`noun` of @, sensory`adj` nut`noun`</li>
257     *     <li>flower`term` : @'s color`adj` flower`noun`, @'s flower`noun`, @'s shape`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun` of @, color`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, flower`noun` of @, ground`noun`    flower`noun`, sensory`adj` flower`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun`-flower`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, shape`adj` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`</li>
258     *     <li>potion`term` : a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` containing a few drops of a color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` filled with a color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` filled with a liquid`adj` color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` half-filled with a liquid`adj` color`adj` liquid`noun`, a calabash`adj` filled with a color`adj` liquid`noun`</li>
259     * </ul>
260     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
261     * first letter of the produced fake word. Capitalizing the second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake
262     * word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it won't change the internally-stored list of words.
263     * @return this for chaining
264     */
265    public Thesaurus addKnownCategories()
266    {
267        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
268        {
269            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
270        }
271        plantTermShuffler =  mappings.get("plant`term`");
272        fruitTermShuffler =  mappings.get("fruit`term`");
273        nutTermShuffler =    mappings.get("nut`term`");  
274        flowerTermShuffler = mappings.get("flower`term`");
275        potionTermShuffler = mappings.get("potion`term`");
276        return this;
277    }
278
279    /**
280     * Given an archive String saved by {@link #archiveCategories()} (probably from another version of SquidLib), this
281     * makes the Thesaurus class act like it did in that archive, assuming the {@link #rng} is seeded the same. This
282     * modifies the {@link #mappings} field and the {@link #categories}, {@link #adjective}, {@link #noun}, and
283     * {@link #nouns} static fields, so it can affect other Thesaurus objects produced later (it won't change
284     * previously-made ones, probably).
285     * 
286     * If you didn't have an archive of the categories from some version of SquidLib, you can download one of the small
287     * files from <a href="https://github.com/yellowstonegames/SquidLib/tree/master/archives">the 'archives' folder of the
288     * SquidLib repo</a>; there's an archive that acts as a snapshot of SquidLib 3.0.0's Thesaurus class, for instance.
289     * If you save the 3.0.0 archive in a libGDX application's assets folder, you can reload the 3.0.0 definitions into
290     * a Thesaurus called {@code myThesaurus} with:
291     * <br>
292     * {@code myThesaurus.addArchivedCategories(Gdx.files.internal("Thesaurus-3-0-0.txt").readString("UTF-8"));}
293     * 
294     * @param archive an archived String of categories produced by {@link #archiveCategories()}
295     * @return this Thesaurus, but static state of the class will also be modified so this may affect other Thesaurus objects
296     */
297    public Thesaurus addArchivedCategories(String archive){
298        final OrderedMap<String, ArrayList<String>> cat = Converters.convertOrderedMap(
299                Converters.convertString,
300                Converters.convertArrayList(Converters.convertString)
301        ).restore(archive);
302        
303        mappings.clear();
304        
305        categories.clear();
306        categories.putAll(cat);
307        
308        adjective.clear();
309        adjective.putAll(cat);
310        
311        noun.clear();
312        noun.putAll(cat);
313        
314        nouns.clear();
315        nouns.putAll(cat);
316        
317        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
318        while (it.hasNext()){
319            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
320                it.remove();
321        }
322        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
323        while (it.hasNext()){
324            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
325                it.remove();
326        }
327        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
328        while (it.hasNext()){
329            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
330                it.remove();
331        }
332
333        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
334        {
335            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
336        }
337        plantTermShuffler =  mappings.get("plant`term`");
338        fruitTermShuffler =  mappings.get("fruit`term`");
339        nutTermShuffler =    mappings.get("nut`term`");
340        flowerTermShuffler = mappings.get("flower`term`");
341        potionTermShuffler = mappings.get("potion`term`");
342
343        return this;
344
345    }
346
347    /**
348     * Adds a large list of words pre-generated by FakeLanguageGen and hand-picked for fitness, and makes them
349     * accessible with a keyword based on the language. The keywords this currently knows:
350     * <br>
351     * "lovecraft`pre`", "english`pre`", "greek_romanized`pre`",
352     * "greek_authentic`pre`", "french`pre`", "russian_romanized`pre`",
353     * "russian_authentic`pre`", "japanese_romanized`pre`", "swahili`pre`",
354     * "somali`pre`", "hindi_romanized`pre`", "arabic_romanized`pre`",
355     * "inuktitut`pre`", "norse`pre`", "nahuatl`pre`", "mongolian`pre`",
356     * "fantasy`pre`", "fancy_fantasy`pre`", "goblin`pre`", "elf`pre`",
357     * "demonic`pre`", "infernal`pre`", "simplish`pre`", "alien_a`pre`",
358     * "korean_romanized`pre`", "alien_e`pre`", "alien_i`pre`", "alien_o`pre`",
359     * "alien_u`pre`", "dragon`pre`", "kobold`pre`", "insect`pre`", "maori`pre`",
360     * "spanish`pre`", "deep_speech`pre`", "norse_simplified`pre`",
361     * "hletkip`pre`", "ancient_egyptian`pre`", "crow`pre`", "imp`pre`",
362     * "malay`pre`", "celestial`pre`", "chinese_romanized`pre`",
363     * "cherokee_romanized`pre`", "vietnamese`pre`"
364     * <br>
365     * These correspond to similarly-named fields in {@link FakeLanguageGen}, just without {@code `pre`}; for instance
366     * {@code "cherokee_romanized`pre`"} corresponds to {@link FakeLanguageGen#CHEROKEE_ROMANIZED}. You can use these
367     * same keywords with {@code `gen`} instead of {@code `pre`} to generate at runtime based on the current RNG state,
368     * instead of using one of several pre-generated words, and doing that does not require addFakeWords() to be used.
369     * <br>
370     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
371     * first letter of the produced fake word, which is often desirable for things like place names. Capitalizing the
372     * second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it
373     * won't change the internally-stored list of words.
374     * @return this for chaining
375     */
376    public Thesaurus addFakeWords()
377    {
378        //long state = rng.getState();
379        for(Map.Entry<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> kv : languages.entrySet())
380        {
381            ArrayList<String> words = new ArrayList<>(16);
382            for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
383                words.add(kv.getValue().word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
384            }
385            addCategory(StringKit.replace(kv.getKey(), "`gen", "`pre"), words);
386        }
387        //rng.setState(state);
388        return this;
389    }
390
391    private StringBuilder modify(CharSequence text)
392    {
393        Matcher m;
394        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(text);
395        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer tb, working = Replacer.wrap(sb);
396        StringBuilder tmp;
397        boolean found;
398        FakeLanguageGen.Alteration alt;
399        for (int a = 0; a < alterations.size(); a++) {
400            alt = alterations.get(a);
401            tmp = working.sb;
402            tb = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(tmp.length()));
403            m = alt.replacer.getPattern().matcher(tmp);
404
405            found = false;
406            while (true) {
407                if (rng.nextDouble() < alt.chance) {
408                    if (!Replacer.replaceStep(m, alt.replacer.getSubstitution(), tb))
409                        break;
410                    found = true;
411                } else {
412                    if (!m.find())
413                        break;
414                    found = true;
415                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, tb);
416                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.MATCH, tb);
417                    m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
418                }
419            }
420            if (found) {
421                m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, tb);
422                working = tb;
423            }
424        }
425        return working.sb;
426
427    }
428    /**
429     * Given a String, StringBuilder, or other CharSequence that should contain words this knows synonyms for, this
430     * replaces each occurrence of such a known word with one of its synonyms, leaving unknown words untouched. Words
431     * that were learned together as synonyms with addSynonyms() will be replaced in such a way that an individual
432     * replacement word should not occur too close to a previous occurrence of the same word; that is, replacing the
433     * text "You fiend! You demon! You despoiler of creation; devil made flesh!", where "fiend", "demon", and "devil"
434     * are all synonyms, would never produce a string that contained "fiend" as the replacement for all three of those.
435     * @param text a CharSequence, such as a String, that contains words in the source language
436     * @return a String of the translated text.
437     */
438    public String process(CharSequence text)
439    {
440//        Replacer rep = wordMatch.replacer(new SynonymSubstitution());
441        //String t = rep.replace(text);
442        Matcher m = wordMatch.matcher(text);
443        Substitution substitution = new SynonymSubstitution();
444        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer dest = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(text.length()));
445        while (m.find()) {
446            if (m.start() > 0) m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, dest);
447            substitution.appendSubstitution(m, dest);
448            m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
449        }
450        m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, dest);
451
452        m.setTarget(dest.sb);
453        dest.sb.setLength(0);
454        while (m.find()) {
455            if (m.start() > 0) m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, dest);
456            substitution.appendSubstitution(m, dest);
457            m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
458        }
459        m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, dest);
460
461        if(alterations.isEmpty())
462            return StringKit.replace(StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(dest.sb), "\t", "");
463        else
464            return StringKit.replace(modify(StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(dest.sb)), "\t", "");
465    }
466
467    public String lookup(String word)
468    {
469        if(word.isEmpty())
470            return word;
471        if("@".equals(word))
472        {
473            return defaultLanguage.word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
474        }
475        String word2 = word.toLowerCase();
476        if(mappings.containsKey(word2))
477        {
478            String nx = mappings.get(word2).next();
479            if(nx.isEmpty())
480                return nx;
481            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
482                return nx.toUpperCase();
483            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
484            {
485                return Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)) + nx.substring(1);
486            }
487            return nx;
488        }
489        else if(languages.containsKey(word2))
490        {
491            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
492                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase();
493            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
494            {
495                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
496            }
497            return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4));
498        }
499        return word;
500    }
501
502    private class SynonymSubstitution implements Substitution
503    {
504        private final StringBuilder temp = new StringBuilder(64);
505        @Override
506        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
507            //dest.append(lookup(match.group(0)));
508            temp.setLength(0);
509            match.getGroup(0, temp);
510            writeLookup(dest, temp);
511        }
512    }
513
514    private void writeLookup(TextBuffer dest, StringBuilder word) {
515        if(word == null || word.length() <= 0)
516            return;
517        if(word.charAt(0) == '@' && word.length() == 1)
518        {
519            dest.append(defaultLanguage.word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
520            return;
521        }
522        else if(mappings.containsKey(word))
523        {
524            String nx = mappings.get(word).next();
525            if(nx.isEmpty())
526                return;
527            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
528            {
529                dest.append(nx.toUpperCase());
530                return;
531            }
532            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
533            {
534                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)));
535                dest.append(nx.substring(1));
536                return;
537            }
538            dest.append(nx);
539            return;
540        }
541        else if(languages.containsKey(word))
542        {
543            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
544            {
545                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase());
546            }
547            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
548            {
549                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
550            }
551            else
552            {
553                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
554            }
555            return;
556        }
557        else if(numbers.containsKey(word))
558        {
559            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
560            {
561                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)).toUpperCase());
562            }
563            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
564            {
565                String w = numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word));
566                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
567                dest.append(w.substring(1));
568            }
569            else
570            {
571                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)));
572            }
573            return;
574        }
575        else if(numberAdjectives.containsKey(word))
576        {
577            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
578            {
579                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)).toUpperCase());
580            }
581            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
582            {
583                String w = numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word));
584                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
585                dest.append(w.substring(1));
586            }
587            else
588            {
589                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)));
590            }
591            return;
592        }
593        if(dest instanceof Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)
594        {
595            ((Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)dest).sb.append(word);
596        }
597        else
598            dest.append(word.toString());
599
600    }
601
602    private class RandomLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
603    {
604        @Override
605        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
606            FakeLanguageGen lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
607            randomLanguages.add(lang);
608            if(match.isCaptured(1))
609            {
610                lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
611                randomLanguages.add(lang);
612                do {
613                    latestGenerated = randomLanguages.get(0).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)))
614                            + "-" + randomLanguages.get(1).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
615                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
616                dest.append(latestGenerated);
617            }
618            else
619            {
620                do{
621                    latestGenerated = lang.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
622                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
623                dest.append(latestGenerated);
624            }
625        }
626    }
627
628    private class KnownLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
629    {
630        public FakeLanguageGen language;
631        public KnownLanguageSubstitution(FakeLanguageGen lang)
632        {
633            language = lang;
634        }
635        @Override
636        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
637            if (match.isCaptured(1)) {
638                do
639                {
640                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5))) +
641                            "-" + language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
642                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
643                dest.append(latestGenerated);
644            } else
645            {
646                do{
647                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
648                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
649                dest.append(latestGenerated);
650            }
651        }
652    }
653
654    /**
655     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth".
656     * May use accented characters, as in
657     * "Thdsh-Hyttilb Hegemony" or "The Glorious Ch Empire"; if you want to strip these out and replace accented
658     * chars with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
659     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
660     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making nation names, by
661     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
662     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the nation name, like "Drayo" in
663     * "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". If more than one language was used in the nation name, as in "Thdsh-Hyttilb
664     * Hegemony", you will have two languages in randomLanguages, so here "Thdsh" would be generated by the first
665     * language, and "Hyttilb" by the second language. Calling this method replaces the current contents of
666     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can. This also assigns the
667     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
668     * "The Glorious Ch Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Ch" at the same time the longer name
669     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
670     *
671     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
672     */
673    public String makeNationName()
674    {
675        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("empire`noun`"))
676        {
677            addKnownCategories();
678        }
679        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
680        int frustration = 0;
681        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
682            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
683        randomLanguages.clear();
684        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
685        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
686        return replacer.replace(working);
687    }
688    /**
689     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth",
690     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. May use accented characters, as in
691     * "Thdsh Hegemony" or "The Glorious Ch Empire",
692     * if the given language can produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars
693     * with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
694     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
695     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this. This assigns the
696     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
697     * "The Glorious Ch Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Ch" at the same time the longer name
698     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
699     * <br>
700     * Some nation names use a hyphenated pairing of what would normally be names in two different languages; if one of
701     * those names is produced by this it will produce two names in the same linguistic style. The randomLanguages field
702     * is not populated by this method; it is assumed that since you are passing this a FakeLanguageGen, you already
703     * have the one you want to use anyway.
704     *
705     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
706     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
707     */
708    public String makeNationName(FakeLanguageGen language)
709    {
710        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("empire`noun`"))
711        {
712            addKnownCategories();
713        }
714        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
715        int frustration = 0;
716        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
717            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
718        randomLanguages.clear();
719        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
720        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
721        return replacer.replace(working);
722    }
723
724    /**
725     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch".
726     * May use accented characters, as in "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
727     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
728     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
729     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
730     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
731     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
732     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
733     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
734     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
735     *
736     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
737     */
738    public String makePlantName()
739    {
740        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("tree`noun`"))
741        {
742            addKnownCategories();
743        }
744        String working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
745        int frustration = 0;
746        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
747            working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
748        randomLanguages.clear();
749        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
750        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
751        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
752    }
753    /**
754     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch",
755     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. May use accented characters, as in
756     * "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
757     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
758     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
759     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
760     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this.
761     *
762     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
763     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
764     */
765    public String makePlantName(FakeLanguageGen language)
766    {
767        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("tree`noun`"))
768        {
769            addKnownCategories();
770        }
771        String working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
772        int frustration = 0;
773        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
774            working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
775        randomLanguages.clear();
776        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
777        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
778        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
779    }

781    /**
782     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "green lime-melon" or "Ung's date".
783     * May use accented characters, as in "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
784     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
785     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
786     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
787     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
788     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
789     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
790     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
791     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
792     *
793     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
794     */
795    public String makeFruitName()
796    {
797        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("fruit`noun`"))
798        {
799            addKnownCategories();
800        }
801        String working = process(fruitTermShuffler.next());
802        int frustration = 0;
803        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
804            working = process(fruitTermShuffler.next());
805        randomLanguages.clear();
806        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
807        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
808        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
809    }
810    /**
811     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "green lime-melon" or "Ung's date",
812     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. May use accented characters, as in
813     * "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
814     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
815     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
816     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
817     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this.
818     *
819     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
820     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
821     */
822    public String makeFruitName(FakeLanguageGen language)
823    {
824        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("fruit`noun`"))
825        {
826            addKnownCategories();
827        }
828        String working = process(fruitTermShuffler.next());
829        int frustration = 0;
830        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
831            working = process(fruitTermShuffler.next());
832        randomLanguages.clear();
833        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
834        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
835        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
836    }

838    /**
839     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "nut of Gikoim" or "Pelyt's cashew".
840     * May use accented characters, as in "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
841     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
842     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
843     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
844     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
845     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
846     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
847     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
848     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
849     *
850     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
851     */
852    public String makeNutName()
853    {
854        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("nut`noun`"))
855        {
856            addKnownCategories();
857        }
858        String working = process(nutTermShuffler.next());
859        int frustration = 0;
860        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
861            working = process(nutTermShuffler.next());
862        randomLanguages.clear();
863        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
864        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
865        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
866    }

895    /**

899     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
900     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
901     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
902     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
903     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
904     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
905     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
906     *
907     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
908     */
909    public String makeFlowerName()

923    }

952    /**
953     * Generates a random possible description for a potion in a container, such as "a smoky glass flask containing a
954     * few drops of an orange tonic", "a milk carton filled with a red fluid", "a shining silver bottle filled with an
955     * effervescent violet potion", or "a wineskin filled with a black serum".
956     *
957     * @return a random description for a potion or other liquid in a container
958     */
959    public String makePotionDescription()
960    {
961        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("liquid`noun`"))
962        {
963            addKnownCategories();
964        }
965        String working = process(potionTermShuffler.next());
966        int frustration = 0;
967        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
968            working = process(potionTermShuffler.next());
969        return StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(working);
970    }
971
972    /**
973     * Gets an English word for a given number, if this knows it. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20
974     * ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers. If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a
975     * String, such as "537" or "-1".
976     * @param number the number to get a word for
977     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)}.
978     */
979    public static String numberWord(final int number)
980    {
981        switch (number){
982            case 0: return "zero";
983            case 1: return "one";
984            case 2: return "two";
985            case 3: return "three";
986            case 4: return "four";
987            case 5: return "five";
988            case 6: return "six";
989            case 7: return "seven";
990            case 8: return "eight";
991            case 9: return "nine";
992            case 10: return "ten";
993            case 11: return "eleven";
994            case 12: return "twelve";
995            case 13: return "thirteen";
996            case 14: return "fourteen";
997            case 15: return "fifteen";
998            case 16: return "sixteen";
999            case 17: return "seventeen";
1000            case 18: return "eighteen";
1001            case 19: return "nineteen";
1002            case 20: return "twenty";
1003            case 30: return "thirty";
1004            case 40: return "fourty";
1005            case 50: return "fifty";
1006            case 60: return "sixty";
1007            case 70: return "seventy";
1008            case 80: return "eighty";
1009            case 90: return "ninety";
1010            case 100: return "hundred";
1011            case 1000: return "thousand";
1012            case 1000000: return "million";
1013            case 1000000000: return "billion";
1014            default: return String.valueOf(number);
1015        }
1016    }
1017
1018    /**
1019     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
1020     * "eleventh"). These words are known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some higher numbers. If a
1021     * word isn't known for a number, this appends a suffix based on the last base-10 digit to the number, as with "0th"
1022     * or "42nd".
1023     * @param number the number to get a position adjective for
1024     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)} followed by a two-char suffix from the last digit.
1025     */
1026    public static String numberAdjective(final int number)
1027    {
1028        switch (number){
1029            case 1: return "first";
1030            case 2: return "second";
1031            case 3: return "third";
1032            case 4: return "fourth";
1033            case 5: return "fifth";
1034            case 6: return "sixth";
1035            case 7: return "seventh";
1036            case 8: return "eighth";
1037            case 9: return "ninth";
1038            case 10: return "tenth";
1039            case 11: return "eleventh";
1040            case 12: return "twelfth";
1041            case 13: return "thirteenth";
1042            case 14: return "fourteenth";
1043            case 15: return "fifteenth";
1044            case 16: return "sixteenth";
1045            case 17: return "seventeenth";
1046            case 18: return "eighteenth";
1047            case 19: return "nineteenth";
1048            case 20: return "twentieth";
1049            case 30: return "thirtieth";
1050            case 40: return "fourtieth";
1051            case 50: return "fiftieth";
1052            case 60: return "sixtieth";
1053            case 70: return "seventieth";
1054            case 80: return "eightieth";
1055            case 90: return "ninetieth";
1056            case 100: return "hundredth";
1057            case 1000: return "thousandth";
1058            case 1000000: return "millionth";
1059            case 1000000000: return "billionth";
1060            default: 
1061            {
1062                switch (number % 10){
1063                    case 1: return number + "st";
1064                    case 2: return number + "nd";
1065                    case 3: return number + "rd";
1066                    default:return number + "th";
1067                }
1068            }
1069        }
1070    }
1071
1072    /**
1073     * Gets an English word for a number, if this knows it, where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and
1074     * highest, both inclusive. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20 ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers.
1075     * If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a String, such as "537" or "-1".
1076     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1077     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1078     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "six" or "eleven", if it is known
1079     */
1080    public String numberWordInRange(int lowest, int highest)
1081    {
1082        return numberWord(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
1083    }
1084    /**
1085     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
1086     * "eleventh"), where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and highest, both inclusive. These words are
1087     * known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some output for other numbers (such as "42nd" or "23rd").
1088     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1089     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1090     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "third" or "twelfth", if it is known
1091     */
1092    public String numberAdjectiveInRange(int lowest, int highest)
1093    {
1094        return numberAdjective(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
1095    }

1423    public static final OrderedMap<String, ArrayList<String>>
1424            adjective = new OrderedMap<>(categories),
1425            noun = new OrderedMap<>(categories),
1426            nouns = new OrderedMap<>(categories);
1427    public static final OrderedMap<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> languages = new OrderedMap<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen>(
1428            FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
1429    static {
1430        for (int i = 0; i < FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length; i++) {
1431            languages.put(FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames[i].replace(' ', '_').toLowerCase() + "`gen`", FakeLanguageGen.registered[i]);
1432        }
1433    }

1485    /**
1486     * Thesaurus preset that changes all text to sound like this speaker: "Desaurus preset dat changez all text to sound
1487     * like dis speakah." You may be familiar with a certain sci-fi game that has orks who sound like this.
1488     */
1489    public static Thesaurus ORK = new Thesaurus("WAAAAAGH!");
1490    static {
1491        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("\\bth", "d"));
1492        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("th", "dd"));
1493        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("er\\b", "ah"));
1494        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("es\\b", "ez"));
1495        ORK.addReplacement("the", "da")
1496                .addReplacement("their", "deyr")
1497                .addReplacement("yes", "ya")
1498                .addReplacement("your", "youse")
1499                .addReplacement("yours", "youses")
1500                .addReplacement("going", "gon'")
1501                .addReplacement("and", "an'")
1502                .addReplacement("to", "*snort*")
1503                .addReplacement("rhythm", "riddim")
1504                .addReplacement("get", "git")
1505                .addReplacement("good", "gud");
1506        
1507        // not related to ORK; this filters out synonyms that aren't in the appropriate list
1508        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
1509        while (it.hasNext()){
1510            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
1511                it.remove();
1512        }
1513        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
1514        while (it.hasNext()){
1515            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
1516                it.remove();
1517        }
1518        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
1519        while (it.hasNext()){
1520            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
1521                it.remove();
1522        }
1523    }
1524
1525    /**
1526     * Gets a stable (large) String that stores all categories this version of Thesaurus knows, as well as all of the
1527     * words each category includes. This can be useful in conjunction with {@link #addArchivedCategories(String)} to
1528     * load a set of categories stored from an earlier version of SquidLib.
1529     * @return a category archive String that can be passed to {@link #addArchivedCategories(String)}
1530     */
1531    public static String archiveCategories(){
1532        return Converters.convertOrderedMap(
1533                        Converters.convertString,
1534                        Converters.convertArrayList(Converters.convertString)
1535                ).stringify(categories);
1536    }
1537}
